cvterm.name: similarity
cvterm.definition: Relation between biological objects that resemble or are related to each other sufficiently to warrant a comparison.

cvterm.name: homology
cvterm.definition: Similarity that results from common evolutionary origin.

cvtermprop.value: This broad definition encompasses all the working definitions proposed so far in the literature.

cvterm.name: homoplasy
cvterm.definition: Similarity that results from independent evolution.

cvterm.name: homocracy
cvterm.definition: Similarity that is characterized by the organization of anatomical structures through the expression of homologous or identical patterning genes.

cvtermprop.value: Homology and homocracy are not mutually exclusive. The homology relationships of patterning genes may be unresolved and thus may include orthologues and paralogues.

cvterm.name: convergence
cvterm.definition: Homoplasy that involves different underlying mechanisms or structures.

cvtermprop.value: Convergence usually implies a notion of adaptation.

cvterm.name: parallelism
cvterm.definition: Homoplasy that involves homologous underlying mechanisms or structures.

cvtermprop.value: Can be applied for features present in closely related organisms but not present continuously in all the members of the lineage.

cvterm.name: structural homology
cvterm.definition: Homology that is defined by similarity with regard to selected structural parameters.

cvterm.name: historical homology
cvterm.definition: Homology that is defined by common descent.

cvterm.name: biological homology
cvterm.definition: Homology that is defined by sharing of a set of developmental constraints, caused by locally acting self-regulatory mechanisms of differentiation, between individualized parts of the phenotype.

cvtermprop.value: Applicable only to morphology. A certain degree of ambiguity is accepted between biological homology and parallelism.

cvterm.name: reversal
cvterm.definition: Homoplasy that involves phenotypes similar to those seen in ancestors within the lineage.

cvterm.name: syntenic homology
cvterm.definition: Structural homology that is detected by similarity in content and organization between chromosomes.

cvterm.name: paralogy
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves genes that diverged after a duplication event.

cvterm.name: syntenic paralogy
cvterm.definition: Paralogy that involves sets of syntenic blocks.

cvterm.name: syntenic orthology
cvterm.definition: Syntenic homology that involves chromosomes of different species.

cvterm.name: partial homology
cvterm.definition: Structural homology that involves complex structures from which only a fraction of the elements that can be isolated are separately homologous.

cvterm.name: protein structural homology
cvterm.definition: Structural homology that is detected at the level of the 3D protein structure, but maybe not at the level of the amino acid sequence.

cvterm.name: non functional homology
cvterm.definition: Structural homology that involves a pseudogenic feature and its functional ancestor.

cvterm.name: orthology
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves genes that diverged after a speciation event.

cvtermprop.value: The term is sometimes also used for anatomical structures.

cvterm.name: xenology
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that is characterized by an interspecies (horizontal) transfer since the common ancestor.

cvtermprop.value: The term is sometimes also used for anatomical structures (e.g. in case of a symbiosis).

cvterm.name: 1 to 1 homology
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves two members sharing no other homologs in the lineages considered.

cvterm.name: 1 to 1 orthology
cvterm.definition: Orthology that involves two genes that did not experience any duplication after the speciation event that created them.

cvterm.name: allogeny (obsolete HOM:0000021)
cvterm.definition: Relationship between recognizably corresponding characters that occurs in two or more taxa and have different generative bases.

cvterm.name: ohnology
cvterm.definition: Paralogy that results from a whole genome duplication event.

cvterm.name: in-paralogy
cvterm.definition: Paralogy that results from a lineage-specific duplication subsequent to a given speciation event.

cvterm.name: out-paralogy
cvterm.definition: Paralogy that results from a duplication preceding a given speciation event.

cvterm.name: pro-orthology
cvterm.definition: 1:many orthology that involves a gene in species A and one of its ortholog in species B, when duplications more recent than the species split have occurred in species B but not in species A.

cvterm.name: semi-orthology
cvterm.definition: 1:many orthology that involves a gene in species A and its ortholog in species B, when duplications more recent than the species split have occurred in species A but not in species B.

cvterm.name: serial homology
cvterm.definition: Iterative homology that involves structures arranged along the main body axis.

cvterm.name: heterochronous homology
cvterm.definition: Biological homology that is characterized by changes, over evolutionary time, in the rate or timing of developmental events of homologous structures.

cvterm.name: paedomorphorsis
cvterm.definition: Heterochronous homology that is produced by a retention in adults of a species of traits previously seen only in juveniles.

cvterm.name: peramorphosis
cvterm.definition: Heterochronous homology that is produced by a maturation of individuals of a species past adulthood, which take on hitherto unseen traits.

cvterm.name: progenesis
cvterm.definition: Paedomorphosis that is produced by precocious sexual maturation of an organism still in a morphologically juvenile stage.

cvterm.name: neoteny
cvterm.definition: Paedomorphosis that is produced by a retardation of somatic development.

cvterm.name: mimicry
cvterm.definition: Convergence that results from co-evolution usually involving an evolutionary arms race.

cvterm.name: 1 to many orthology
cvterm.definition: Orthology that involves two genes when duplications more recent than the species split have occurred in one species but not the other.

cvterm.name: many to many homology
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves two members of a larger set of homologs.

cvterm.name: 1 to many homology
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves a structure that has no other homologs in the species in which it is defined, and several homologous structures in another species.

cvterm.name: apomorphy
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that is based on recent shared ancestry, characterizing a monophyletic group.

cvterm.name: plesiomorphy
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that is based on distant shared ancestry.

cvtermprop.value: This term is usually contrasted to apomorphy.

cvterm.name: deep homology
cvterm.definition: Homocracy that involves morphologically and phylogenetically disparate structures that are the result of parallel evolution.

cvtermprop.value: Used for structures in distantly related taxa.

cvterm.name: hemiplasy
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that is characterized by topological discordance between a gene tree and a species tree attributable to the phylogenetic sorting of genetic polymorphisms across successive nodes in a species tree.

cvterm.name: gametology
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves not recombining and subsequently differentiated sex chromosomes.

cvterm.name: chromosomal homology
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves the chromosomes able to pair (synapse) during meiosis.

cvterm.name: many to many orthology
cvterm.definition: Orthology that involves two genes that experienced duplications more recent than the species split that created them.

cvterm.name: within-species paralogy
cvterm.definition: Paralogy that involves genes from the same species.

cvterm.name: between-species paralogy
cvterm.definition: Paralogy that involves genes from different species.

cvtermprop.value: The genes have diverged before a speciation event.

cvterm.name: postdisplacement
cvterm.definition: Paedomorphosis that is produced by delayed growth of immature structures into the adult form.

cvterm.name: hypermorphosis
cvterm.definition: Peramorphosis that is produced by a delay in the offset of development.

cvterm.name: synology
cvterm.definition: Xenology that results, not from the transfer of a gene between two species, but from a hybridization of two species.

cvterm.name: isoorthology
cvterm.definition: Orthology that involves functional equivalent genes with retention of the ancestral function.

cvterm.name: tandem paralogy
cvterm.definition: Paralogy that is characterized by duplication of adjacent sequences on a chromosome segment.

cvterm.name: latent homology
cvterm.definition: Parallelism that involves morphologically very similar structures, occurring only within some members of a taxon and absent in the common ancestor (which possessed the developmental basis to develop this character).

cvtermprop.value: Used for structures in closely related taxa.

cvterm.name: syngeny
cvterm.definition: Homocracy that involves recognizably corresponding characters that occurs in two or more taxa, or as a repeated unit within an individual.

cvtermprop.value: Cannot be used when orthologous patterning gene are organizing obviously non-homologous structures in different organisms due for example to pleiotropic functions of these genes.

cvterm.name: apparent orthology
cvterm.definition: Between-species paralogy that involves single copy paralogs resulting from reciprocal gene loss.

cvtermprop.value: The genes are actually paralogs but appear to be orthologous due to differential, lineage-specific gene loss.

cvterm.name: pseudoparalogy
cvterm.definition: Xenology that involves genes that ended up in a given genome as a result of a combination of vertical inheritance and horizontal gene transfer.

cvtermprop.value: These genes may come out as paralogs in a single-genome analysis.

cvterm.name: equivalogy
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves functional equivalent genes with retention of the ancestral function.

cvtermprop.value: This may include examples of orthology, paralogy and xenology.

cvterm.name: interology
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves orthologous pairs of interacting molecules in different organisms.

cvterm.name: functional equivalence
cvterm.definition: Similarity that is characterized by interchangeability in function.

cvterm.name: iterative homology
cvterm.definition: Biological homology that involves parts of the same organism.

cvterm.name: paraxenology
cvterm.definition: Xenology that is characterized by multiple horizontal transfer events, resulting in the presence of two or more copies of the foreign gene in the host genome.

cvterm.name: plerology
cvterm.definition: Paralogy that is characterized by extra similarity between paralogous sequences resulting from concerted evolution.

cvtermprop.value: This phenomenon is usually due to gene conversion process.

cvterm.name: homotopy
cvterm.definition: Structural homology that involves structures with the same or similar relative positions.

cvtermprop.value: Theissen (2005) mentions that some authors may consider homotopy to be distinct from homology, but this is not the standard use.

cvterm.name: homeosis
cvterm.definition: Biological homology that involves an ectopic structure and the normally positioned structure.

cvterm.name: homoeology
cvterm.definition: Synology that results from allopolyploidy.

cvtermprop.value: On a long term, it is hard to distinguish allopolyploidy from whole genome duplication.

cvterm.name: paramorphism
cvterm.definition: Iterative homology that involves two structures, one of which originated as a duplicate of the other and co-opted the expression of patterning genes of the ancestral structure.

cvterm.name: regulogy
cvterm.definition: Historical homology that involves orthologous pairs of transcription factors and downstream regulated genes in different organisms.
